docs.lead_paragraph: Besides questioning the long-term efficacy of treating addiction by creating addiction, critics of methadone maintenance programs have cautioned that, without strict monitoring and control, the programs might become part of the problem they were designed to solve. Their concerns were given credence last week in a report submitted by the Legislative Commission on Expenditure Review, detailing abuses in New York State's methadone ''take-home'' program that may contribute to overdoses and death through illegal resale of the drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: In his budget for the coming year, President Reagan proposes substantial cuts in such Government benefit programs as welfare, food stamps, Medicaid, Medicare and subsidized housing. The budget, made public today, calls for changes in the laws under which millions of Americans are entitled to Federal benefits if they meet eligibility criteria. The changes would reduce the cost of social programs by $12.8 billion from amounts otherwise anticipated. But the overall cost of the entitlement programs, according to the Office of Management and Budget, would still rise to a record of $184.4 billion in the 1983 fiscal year. That would be a 9.9 percent increase from the 1981 total.

docs.lead_paragraph: Too often people learn what is -and, more important, what is not - covered by their medical insurance policies the hard way: when faced with a staggering bill for services they thought were covered. In other cases people miss out on services or reimbursement because they do not realize what is due them or how to file and follow through on a claim. A national survey by the Rand Corporation published last summer found that when the policy required that a deductible (the amount the consumer Third of a series on various forms of insurance that is appearing periodically on the Style page and in The Home Section. must pay before insurance coverage takes effect) be satisfied, only about half the insured families knew they were entitled to reimbursement for outpatient physician services and prescription drugs. Still others who think they are adequately covered could face financial ruin because their policies have failed to keep pace with the soaring increases in the costs of medical care. Those policies that reimburse patients a specified amount for each hospital day may no longer be adequate now that the average hospital charges $151 a day for a semiprivate room.

docs.lead_paragraph: FEW drugs have had as great an impact on medicine as the beta blockers. Since the first of this cl ass of synthetic drugs was marketed in 1 965, doctors have prescribed them for a wide variety of conditions, r anging from heart disease, the nation's leading killer, to such seemi ngly minor but potentially incapacitating disorders as stage fright. The list continues to grow, and recent studies have shown that the beta blockers can help lower significantly the incidence of fatal and nonfatal heart attacks among people who have already had one. It is now clear that beta blockers are one of those infrequent advances that revolutionize the practice of medicine. They are ''one of the major therapeutic advances of this century,'' according to a textbook on the beta blockers by Dr. William H. Frishman, a cardiologist at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. And Dr. Sidney Alexander of the Lahey Clinic in Boston calls them ''perhaps the most significant advance in the treatment of coronary disease since the discovery of nitroglycerin,'' first used in 1879 to treat the chest pains of angina.

headline.main: NEW CLASS OF DRUGS REVOLUTIONIZES THERAP Y FOR HEART DISEASE
